reviewText:
I'm always chasing roguelike dungeon games, even though most of them end up pretty bad. The reason I do this is because every so often, I find a game like Tallowmere!

I absolutely love this game. It's equal parts fun and frustrating. You really learn and develop your tactics the more you play. You have to figure out the best way to use your weapons, and what weapon is the right weapon to use in any given situation, and even once you've learned that, you have to be careful not to get too cocky or careless, because mistakes can kill!

There's nothing better than the thrill of demolishing enemies with the katana, or raining grenades down upon the unsuspecting mobs below, or sneaking up behind and stabbing an enemy with an emerald dagger. You find a rocket launcher for the first time and go nuts with it! Then you realize that the subtleties of the ice wand are sometimes preferable, even if the wand doesn't have the launcher's range.

You die. You die again. You curse the mobs and you curse yourself for not being good enough to get past the mobs yet, or making a stupid mistake. You quit the game in frustration. But then you go back, because you know you can take everything you've learned and make it a little further next time, and sure enough, you do!

It's so wonderfully retro in that it's the sort of game that you just have to keep working and working to perfect your reactions, your tactics, your skills. It's brutally unforgiving when you mess up, but your willingness to soldier on and learn from those mistakes is rewarded when you post a new top score on your personal scoreboard. It's got all the punishing beauty of a classic arcade game. Instant favorite game for me!

reviewText:
There are roguelikes and rogue-lites that are difficult, but satisfying because of their polish and depth. There are also roguelikes and rogue-lites that are difficult, but unpolished and lacking in depth. This game qualifies as the latter.

This game is plagued by repetition and artificial difficulty. Its repetition stems from the lack of variety in dungeon creation, the lack of diversity in the weapons you'll be using in one run, and the lack of enemy variety. Starting with dungeon creation, I'd like to say that I'm a roguelike enthusiast and I have an appreciate for randomly generated environments, as well as difficult games that require you to learn and think critically... when they are done properly. Many roguelikes include exceptions and special cases in their procedural generation to aid the player and the eliminate unfairness. Tallowmere, however, does not take this into account. In my short time with the game, I was forced to take damage because of poor trap placement; I was required to drive my body through saw blades to progress, and I was forced to sit in poisonous gas to reach certain areas. The often awkward and clunky ways in which the dungeon walls affect your movement has already had me slamming my face into spiked walls, which litter nearly a third of the walls in the game and are placed thoughtlessly.

While there are numerous weapons, the weapons you'll be using almost exclusively are those that benefit from your armor. If you have a shield that confers +5 damage to ice wands, why would you be using anything else unless strictly required to do so (which is often based on the poor dungeon generation qualities mentioned before)? On top of that, many of the weapons have strange and inconsistent interactions with enemies and the environment. If an enemy is near a wall and you're trying to take him out with a melee weapon, you're just as likely to hit the wall and be immobilized for a second or so.

Enemy diversity is, at least within the first 15 rooms or so, very lacking. You'll be fighting the same 5-8 enemies over and over, and a number of them aren't even distinct enough from other enemies to qualify as their own entity. Further, the inclusion of the Ogres
date: the potion-throwing annoyances that can end a run without even showing up on your screen by stunning you, are dreadful (in the bad way). If the developers saw a need to include a potion specifically designed to ward the frustrations of one enemy, why even include the enemy? Additionally, the potions are heat-seeking and they go through walls (they also speed up the longer they're in the air, but that's a different frustration entirely), which, for me, at least, was extremely off-putting and difficult to adjust to.\n\nThis game looked interesting to me; it looked sort of like Magicite, but the $5 price tag made me wary. Then, I thought, many great roguelikes and rogue-lites are free or cheaper than $5, so I gave this game a chance. My conclusion is thus: this game feels like it's in a very early beta stage. It feels like nothing in the game works the way it was intended to, but that the developers decided that it was fine to release anyway. The game is a total mess, but really only because of some issues that have simple fixes. It's a game I'll be keeping my eye on, but it's a game I won't be enjoying any time soon. If you're a fan of polished and satisfying roguelikes/lites, I would stay away from this game. However, if you're not so familiar with superior roguelike elements and you have $5 to drop on a cute time-waster, this might be the game for you.

Quite possibly the most barebones roguelite game I've ever played. However, I got a bit of enjoyment out of it, so let's go through the Pros and Cons:


+Addictive: If you're the type who delights in combat in which you are invariably victorious, you'll enjoy this game, with its rampant explosions, fancy level up decals, and flying chunks of gore.
+Variable Difficulty: There are options in place that let you make the game harder or easier. They exist, but I haven't really felt the need to use them.
+Weapon Variety: There are several classes of weapons that (despite their incongruency with each other and/or the game's hardly-there theming) are actually pretty unique when compared to each other.
-Cheap Shots: There are two actual threats to you in this game: Ogres that throw purple stunning potions, and Elite enemies, which take much longer to kill and do a lot more damage. This is how Tallowmere does difficulty.
-Enemies, or, a lack thereof. There are maybe seven enemy types in this game. They all do one thing, and have no other features other than that.
-A lack of direction. There's a character called Lady Tallowmere. She has a dangerous dungeon. You go into it. That's it. OH NO SHE GETS KIDNAPPED! Oh you just rescued her. Oh look, weird potions on the ground that do inexplicable things. They're gone by the next room. That's all the story you're getting.


I could go on, but continuing to write this is like continuing in Tallowmere: increasingly boring and relatively pointless.

reviewText: The best way to describe it is simply like many others have been: A roguelike platformer. You run through procedurally generated dungeon rooms one by one, slaying the enemies to drop a key to the next room. It sounds simple enough, but it gets very intense the more you go in. The game can quickly run from walk-in-the-park to hair-pulling difficult in the time of one room change, and when you die... You're dead for good, having to start over from square one. One of the really neat things I've seen in this game is how the random generation doesn't apply only to items/equipment and the dungeon rooms themselves, but also to the objectives. In one playthrough, the 7th floor required me to slay the mighty Hydra, while the second runthrough I was asked to retrieve Lady Tallowmere's flag. This is a really nice thought by the dev, as it keeps it more interesting in terms of what you have to accomplish to advance throughout Tallowmere's brutish dungeon. This is a very fun game that has hours upon hours of playability in it, and I'd recommend it to anyone who loves Rogue-likes, Rogue-lites, and Metroidvania-style RPGs. Although at times it can feel a little frustrating, you'll quickly notice the fun factor easily overshadows these moments.

reviewText:
This action platformer roguelite is a button-masher's dream. It's a game that really wants you to go in swinging, presenting frequent opportunities for frenetic action that will either leave you alone and surrounded by the viscera of your enemies, or bleeding out on the dungeon floor.

You like to double-jump? Heck, go ahead and do it ad infinitum -- you can basically fly. Your weapons swing/fire fast and deadly, and your shield can block most shots perfectly. So, you feel powerful, but there's still a great challenge, because the levels and enemies are just as unforgiving as the power curve is generous.

It has its rough edges, and definitely has the feel of a one man effort. My biggest gripe is with item selection -- you hit up and down on the game pad to choose your weapon or item, which is both easy to do on accident and easy to lose track of. You just picked up two new weapons; quick, how many taps to get back to the ice wand when you need it? Oh no, you accidentally selected your only health potion and used that instead? Too bad. Yeah, that could definitely be way better. Also some annoyances with the game pad setup (it detects a different device as player 1 than most other games, and at one point my triggers stopped working and had to be remapped). I wish they weren't there, but they don't stop me from playing at all.

Tallowmere provides nice bite-sized action if you want it, or a more substantial progressive challenge requiring practice and skill development if you want to go deep on it. I think it would appeal well to fans of Spelunky, so if you like that game you might give this one a try as well.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game. The graphics are so crisp and lovely to look at. The gameplay, at least to me, feels like a bit of a mix between Rogue Legacy and (at least the combat in) Terraria. The combat is very satisfying. You can attack as quickly as you can click the mouse/ press the button.

The game works really nicely with a controller, and although it feels like a lot of multitasking at first, you'll quickly get the hang of smashing foes from left to right all the while using your (might I say) vital shield to protect you from incoming attacks.

The movement is incrediby fluid. While I would like it if the shield switched directions if you press different directions, it does make some things easier, such as backing away from enemies.

There appears to be quite a number of weapons, all the ones that I have used so far have been really neat and responsive.

This is definitely a high quality rogue-like game which I think will share the same pedestal as some of the greats currently available. It doesn't feel like a cheap game, which makes it more than worth the price considering some of the features such as randomly generated rooms that get bigger and more challenging as you progress. There's a lot of loot, a lot of waypoints for you to teleport quickly to be healed entirely for free and then return, all within a few seconds.

This game has so much of what I look for in a rogue-like; number 1 being replay value. The dungeons are apparently endless, so you basically just progress as far as you can before submitting to your inevitable fate.

There is also infinite jumping and lots of sparkles. Need I say more?

This game is a tedious, monotonous waste of time, with bare bones gameplay and very little to keep it fresh, gameplay consists of mashing left arrow key to attack and occasionally holding right to block everything directly in front of you forever, so if you like turtling behind a tower shield followed by spamming rockets/grenades/ice in one general direction and having them automatically target enemies with no personal aim whatsoever you'll have a gotdang blast.

I managed to get to floor 45 on only my 5th life with full otherworldy gear and no kittens sacrificed and it got to the point where I was running blindly at everything mashing attack because there was little reason not to. The only thing stopping you from running full-tilt into all danger is the presense of ogres who throw stunning potions that home in on you and never ever miss ever, requiring you to use the shield, but since you can buy 5 minute stun-proofing potions for half a ha'penny they're not an issue either at later levels.

No weapons have attacking speeds, they go as fast as you can mash the attack button (which is the left arrow key for no discernable reason) so there's really no reason to not nuke every room with a rocket launcher and grenades from several lightyears away. Boss monsters include a giant cat who fires shots that you have to block before you attack, a giant flying robot which requires you to block his shots and then attack, and a giant three-headed hydra that has you blocking shots and then attacking. You can see we have a very diverse spread there.

The first 25-30 floors have events sprinkled throughout them to make them interesting but after that the next 20 or so  have nothing but more empty space and more of the same seven monsters to fight, three of which do nearly the exact same thing and two of which that do the exact same thing entirely. I also wasn't kidding about empty space because the levels are completely 100% randomly generated and a lot of the time it's nothing but a giant room full of enemies shooting undodgable lightning and stun potions. The generator for the levels is painfully lazy as well, traps can be placed in any spot, so when a giant circular saw is in the middle of a hallway with no way around it you're just going to have to take a hit. When I got to hour two of this game I thought to myself, This is actually pretty good for an early access title

reviewText:
For 5$, Tallowmere is an absolute indie gem. The graphics (read: tilesets) are a bit repetitive, but they are good. Grungey yet crisp. I feel like the character's sprite art (this includes weapons/armor) could be a bit better. but to me, this seems like a stylistic choice. The focus is on the gameplay...so on to the gameplay...

It is almost like a 2D platformer meeting an oldschool arena shooter like quake or unreal tournament. The movement is a bit slow, which is fine. Tactical yet makes things challenging. The twist that reminds me of the oldschool games, however, is the ability to jump infinitely, floating through the air like a maddened butterfly throwing grenades and shooting rockets. For those struggling, there is a hilarious and very saddening (for some) mechanic that allows you to make the game easier, be that for learning or for casual play, do note that this puts you in a different highscore bracket. There is a variety of weapons and enemies that will all change the way you interact with them slightly, keeping things fresh and interesting.

My favorite thing about this game is the tutorial...or lack there of.

Let me explain. It doesn't hold your hand and let you go through a cheesemode scenario where you kill one bad guy and as you work your way through the platforming mechanics to get to them, it spews dialogue at your face that you can't skip, and its voiced, and assumes you are an idiot. No, Tallowmere respects you. Tallowmere gives you a few NPCs you have the option to talk to or not, some helpful unobstructive messages at the top of your screen, some kittens, and an escape menu to view tips and tricks before sending you on your journey. If you like games like Rogue Legacy or Legend of Dungeon, or any rogue-lites/roguelikes or fun action platformers, you will probably love Tallowmere. Pick it up.

reviewText:
I was so excited for this game! It is a great idea in theory but 4 things make this game a DON'T BUY:

1) The animation is truly terrible. This is coming from somebody whose first video game system was an Atari 2600! Video game sprites from the 80's had 2 frames of animation for movement. 30 years later, we can offer at least that much! With almost zero animation (but the odd super-cool flame or blood effect), it feels less like a video game and more like a comic book with no dialogue or storyline. It removes a lot of the fun and immersion. Original roguelikes have zero animation as well but they have a lot more depth in their mechanics, which I will get into later.

2) If the animation is not there, at least give me some variety in enemy attacks. Most enemies are just long-range attackers and that makes each run incredibly dependent on weapon drops. The grenade and rocket-launcher are so useful and everything else...not so much. The other weapons each have glaring weaknesses and your game is reduced to spamming grenades and rockets from an extremely far and safe distance. If that is the gameplay, I really don't need monsters and shields and tactics. I can just shoot rockets and grenades into an empty pit and listen to the explosions, right? Shallow mechanics.

3) The dungeons have a random layout, so nothing was designed with playability in mind. This sounds like it will always be fresh but it is often frustrating because you cannot see what you are walking into and you can end up dead in an instant. You can move slowly to avoid trouble but you can easily trigger an impossible situation where your death is nearly guaranteed unless you slaughter all monsters in an instant or make an amazing escape. Of course, this won't happen if you just carpetbomb all open spaces with grenades and rockets.

4)  No static unlocks. This is easily the worst part of Tallowmere and it kills the game. Playing a game that starts over from the beginning every time is fine if it is an arcade experience. But arcade experiences do not have random death from procedurally-generated dungeons. Imagine if you put a quarter into an arcade machine and the game randomly just blew up your ship after 2-5 seconds? If you cannot save the game and no levels or gear or stats carry over, you need some sort of progression via learning the game. Even a fighting game that has no saves and random enemy strategies doesn't have random enemy attacks. Chun-Li's kicks will not suddenly do more damage because she is a randomly higher-level/big-head" Chun-Li.

TL;DR The challenge is supposed to be random
